47:03 Caption: There will be nothing more to see in the first half. The whistle blowing of Nicola Rizzoli has ended it.
47:04 Caption: Today's clash hasn't been that attractive up to now, but it hasn't been a total borefest. There have been a few nice movements for both sides. AS Roma have arguably been the better of the two sides in the first half. The home side is creating their opportunities using lightning-fast counter-attacks. The tactic of the away side is slow build-up play.

49:03 Caption: Nothing more will happen in this game as the referee blows for full time.
49:04 Caption: Today's game was very poor. There weren't many thrilling moments. AS Roma had more of the game and were superior. Their manager will certainly be the happier of the two managers. In terms of strategy, the hosts were waiting for the right moment to win the ball and launch a counter-attack. The visiting side adopted a possession style of football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a closely-contested Serie A match, Genoa hosted AS Roma at the Luigi Ferraris Stadium with a final score favoring the visitors, 1-0. The game, dominated by defensive strategies and intermittent offensive bursts, left plenty to discuss.

From the very first kick-off, taken by Genoa, the pace and intensity of the game were evident. Within the first minute, Genoa managed to test the AS Roma defense with a shot on target, signaling their aggressive intentions right from the outset. However, a quick succession of phases saw the ball go out of play and an early corner taken by Genoa, only to be cleared away by AS Roma’s resolute defense. 

Immediately following this, an attempt by AS Roma to establish their presence was evident as they launched two quick shots on target within seconds of each other, a clear indication of their intent to maintain attacking pressure. Eugenio Lamanna, Genoa's goalkeeper, remained composed and dealt with the threats efficiently. The pattern seemed to set the tone for the defensive resilience and careful probing that characterized much of the match.

Subsequently, there were periods of ball clearance and throw-ins with both sides struggling to maintain a fluid possession game. In the 8th minute, Genoa made an early substitution, signaling perhaps a tactical adjustment to counter AS Roma's pressing game. The small intervals of play were punctuated by throw-ins and clearances, making it a very stop-start affair that disrupted the flow for both teams.

Around the 10th minute, there was a fleeting moment of AS Roma brilliance when Emerson sent a dangerous ball into the Genoa box, only for the keeper Lamanna to comfortably gather it. AS Roma's Kevin Strootman then made another attempt with a lofted cross but once again, Genoa's defense was alert, resulting in a forced corner. Bruno Peres of AS Roma attempted a short corner, which proved fruitless, leading to a sequence of throw-ins and clearances. 

The tempo rose as AS Roma’s Emerson again made himself known, exploiting a precise pass to fire a low shot towards the left side of the goal. Lamanna was up to the task, showcasing his acrobatic skills to deny what seemed a certain goal. Tensions rose as fouls began to disrupt play – Genoa’s persistent infringement forced the referee to call several indirect free-kicks.

As the first half progressed, Genoa's Darko Lazovic sent intriguing crosses into AS Roma's penalty area which Wojciech Szczesny successfully intercepted. Amid these exchanges, Genoa's Lucas Ocampos collected a ball on the edge of the box and poised to strike goal-wards, only for the shot to be saved brilliantly. Genoa picked up a yellow card, with Isaac Cofie booked for a foul, a testament to the growing pressures and physicality of the game.

The 35th minute unfurled the game-defining moment; an unfortunate own goal by Armando Izzo of Genoa, who mistakenly redirected a cross into the bottom left corner of his own net, thus handing AS Roma the lead. The incident undeniably lifted AS Roma's spirits as their possession game increased in intensity. The first half concluded with AS Roma maintaining control but not without Genoa challenging through neat passing movements and sporadic shots that tested the visitors' resolve.

Post the break, AS Roma kicked off the second half with renewed vigor. A measured cross from Bruno Peres nearly set up a perfect scoring opportunity, but the final execution went awry. The initial minutes saw AS Roma maintaining a high line and pressing deeply into Genoa’s half. Not long after, Genoa’s Darko Lazovic put in an effortful cross into AS Roma's box, but it was fended off. Soon after, Radja Nainggolan saw his deft attempt from the edge of the box blocked, consistent with the proficient performance of Genoa’s defensive structure.

A few minutes over the hour mark, AS Roma’s Dzeko forced Lamanna into a significant save to keep the scoreline tight, an effort which earned AS Roma another corner. Unfortunately, for them, this too didn’t yield any additional goals.

Genoa, persistently pushing for an equalizer, found themselves frequently interceded by AS Roma’s organized defense. Even an audacious long ball attempt from Ezequiel Munoz intended to catch Szczesny off-guard, found no success. The closing stages saw further substitutions with AS Roma electing to bring fresh legs on the field to bolster defensive solidity and maintain their slender lead.

Late efforts from Genoa, including a speculative yet close long-range free-kick by Mauricio Pinilla, which veered over the bar, all bore testimony to their relentless pursuit of an equalizer. However, AS Roma’s defensive discipline held firm.

Throughout the match, individual moments of brilliance interspersed with tactical fouls led to a fair share of yellow cards from both sides. Key players like Antonio Rudiger, Daniele De Rossi, and Kevin Strootman for AS Roma, and Lucas Ocampos for Genoa, found their names added to the referee's book, reinforcing the competitive nature of this encounter.

In the end, the match concluded with AS Roma maintaining their lead. The visitors' manager would surely be content with the role of his defense and the critical own goal provision by Genoa's Izzo, which effectively became the match-winner. Genoa, despite creating substantial chances and displaying spirited football, fell short in the finishing department.

A detailed observation of the match reveals Genoa's strategy was geared towards counter-attacking play, utilizing speed to break through AS Roma’s possession-based approach. Conversely, AS Roma displayed patience, relying on slow build-ups to draw the opposition out of position. Incisive offensive movements from both ends, marked by ample shots on target and crucial saves, defined the closeness of the contest.

Ultimately, the game, interspersed with several thrilling moments, ended favoring AS Roma, who seized the key moment and held onto their lead until the final whistle. It’s worth noting that while the singular goal originated from an own goal, AS Roma's persistence in keeping Genoa on edge and maintaining ball possession played a critical role in their overall successful performance. 

The match would leave Genoa reflecting on their finishing woes and looking towards improving their defensive communication, while AS Roma would move forward with the satisfaction of a hard-earned win bolstered by a strong defensive display and the ability to capitalize on opposition errors.
